original: HOLMBERG, Bror Alexander Ludvig, Professor, f Nättraby, Blek l, 30/7 81 av sjökapt M H o Anna Lengquist, gm Anna Olsson. Mog.ex Kkrona 99, fil kand Lund 02, fil lic 05 o fil dr 06. Aman v kem inst i Lund 03—04 0 05—07, doc i kemi Lund 06—15, lär i allm kemi inom medic fakult där 09—13 o 14—15, tf laborator i kemi 14, prof i org o analyt kemi KTH 15—19, prof i org kemi där 20—43, prof i org: kemi v KVA fr 44. Led av Riks-kommiss:s f ekon försv.beredsk kem beredsk.-kté sed. 36, av Försv.väs:s kem anst:s veten-skapl råd sed. 37, ordf i stift Graf Forskn.lab 42, sakk v prof.tillsättn i Upps 18, Hfors 28 o 40, Sthlm 31, Oslo 33, Gbg 34 o Trondheim 37, insp f Sv Gasverksfrns yrkessk fr 21, led av Ramsay-ktén 21—32, ex.omb v tekn gymn 22— 24, censor v studex 31—33. Led av Deutsche chemische Gesellschaft fr 08 o styr.led där 27 —29; led av Sv Tekn.frn fr 15, styr.led i dess avd T 17, 23—24 o 31, i avd KB 18—20, avd:s v. ordf 19 o dess ordf 20; hed.led av Lunds Kem Frn 15; led av Sv Kem Ind.kont fr 18; Sv Pappers- o Cellulosaing.frn fr 23; lea av dess forskn.kté 27; ordf i Kemistsamf 25—34; led av Finland Kemistsamf fr 27, av American Chemical Soc fr 29, av VA:s Nobelkté f kemi fr 34. LIVA, LVA, LFS, LVS; LNVA; KVA:s Lindblomska belön 16 o halva Wallmarkska d :o 18, Kemistsamf :s Nor-blad-EkstrandM 19, Upps univ:s Björkénska pr 31, IVA :s GMM öv Peter Klason 43. Studieres t Norge, Danm, Tyskl, Schweiz, Engl, Frankr, Ital o Holl. Av trycket: Ett flert avhandl i org kemi.
translated: HOLMBERG, Bror Alexander Ludvig, Professor, born in Nättraby, Blekinge, on July 30, 1881, son of sea captain M.H. Holmberg and Anna Lengquist, married to Anna Olsson. Completed Merchant Navy Officer Training in 1899, Bachelor of Arts degree from Lund University in 1902, Licentiate degree in 1905 and Doctorate in 1906. Assistant at the Chemical Institute in Lund from 1903-1904 and 1905-1907, Docent in Chemistry at Lund University from 1906-1915, taught general chemistry within the Medical Faculty from 1909-1913 and 1914-1915, temporary laboratory manager in Chemistry in 1914, Professor of Organic and Analytical Chemistry at the Royal Institute of Technology (KTH) from 1915-1919, Professor of Organic Chemistry at KTH from 1920-1943, Professor of Organic Chemistry at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences from 1944. Member of the National Economic Defense Commission's Chemical Defense Committee since 1936, member of the Defense Administration's Chemical Agency's scientific council since 1937, chairman of the Graf Research Laboratory Foundation since 1942, expert in professorial appointments at Uppsala in 1918, Helsinki in 1928 and 1940, Stockholm in 1931, Oslo in 1933, Gothenburg in 1934 and Trondheim in 1937, inspector of the Swedish Gasworks Profession School since 1921, member of the Ramsay Committee from 1921-1932, examiner at the Technical Gymnasium from 1922-1924, censor for the Matriculation Examination from 1931-1933. Member of the German Chemical Society since 1908 and served on the board from 1927-1929; member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences since 1915, served on the board in section T in 1917, 1923-1924 and 1931, in section KB in 1918-1920, vice chairman in 1919 and chairman in 1920; honorary member of the Lund Chemical Society since 1915; member of the Swedish Chemical Industry Control since 1918; member of the Swedish Paper and Cellulose Industry Research Committee since 1923, chairman of the committee in 1927; chairman of the Swedish Chemical Society from 1925-1934; member of the Finnish Chemical Society since 1927, American Chemical Society since 1929, and the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences' Nobel Committee for Chemistry since 1934. Member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Letters, History and Antiquities; Royal Physiographic Society in Lund; Royal Society of Sciences in Uppsala; Royal Society of Sciences in Gothenburg; Swedish Society for Technological Sciences, served on the board of section T in 1917, 1923-1924 and 1931, section KB in 1918-1920, vice chairman in 1919 and chairman in 1920; received the Lindblom Award from the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1916 and half of the Wallmark Award in 1918, Nor-blad-Ekstrand Medal of the Swedish Chemical Society in 1919, Björkén Prize from Uppsala University in 1931, and the Peter Klason Award from the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences in 1943. Studied in Norway, Denmark, Germany, Switzerland, England, France, Italy, and the Netherlands. Numerous papers published in the field of organic chemistry.
